text: I think one of the great myths is that
we are overdiagnosing and overtreating
and overmedicating the children of
America nothing could be furthered from
the truth while there's tremendous
increase in the identification of
something like attention deficit
hyperactivity disorder and therefore
more children able to get a hold of
medication um the overwhelming majority
um do not get identified and don't get
treated the good news is that these
medicines have been available since the
no one has ever died of taking a psycho
stimulant like adero or dexin or Rin and
more importantly kids who get treated
early are less likely to use illicit
drugs than kids who don't get treated or
kids who get treated late when you have
ADHD and it makes perfect sense if you
don't diagnose and treat a real
psychiatric illness and a kid feels
demoralized and feels irritable and
feels terrible about themselves and
about their self-esteem the psychiatric
medicines don't work they start treating
themselves with alcohol with marijuana
with cocaine with Ecstasy with illicit
drugs with cigarettes and so ignoring
these disorders and worrying about the
fact that we're medicating too much when
in reality I think we need to get better
at identifying kids when they're in
trouble recognizing that these are not
feel-good medicines they have no stre
you know they're you know take this pill
take this Prozac you'll feel better in
six weeks you know it has no street
value um is really a problem and that
America has to get their head around the
fact that psychiatric illness is real um
and at times needs not only real
treatments like cognitive behavioral
therapy or behavioral treatment um or
whether it's a remediation or
accommodations for learning but also
needs medications at time and with
medication there's always the risk of
side effects and the potential of um of
a positive effect that at the end of the
day will let a child or a teenager uh
truly live to truly be able to live a
full life at work at school at play and
and love you know with friends and with
their family
